Here are two excellent croissant recipes I found, ranging from a simplified beginner-friendly version to a more traditional approach:

## **Recipe 1: Quick and Easy Croissants (Simplified Method)**

This recipe from Supergolden Bakes offers a "simplified quick-method dough" that's "great for beginners and well worth the effort!"[1](https://www.supergoldenbakes.com/quick-and-easy-croissants-from-scratch/)

**Ingredients:**
- 250g (2 cups) strong bread flour
- 150g (⅔ cup) cold unsalted butter, cubed
- 120ml (½ cup) tepid milk
- 3 tbsp sugar
- 7g (1 sachet) dry active yeast
- ½ tsp salt
- 1 egg yolk beaten with 1 tbsp milk for glazing[1](https://www.supergoldenbakes.com/quick-and-easy-croissants-from-scratch/)

**Instructions:**

**Dough Preparation:** Create the dough using the simplified folding method where you "fold the short sides of the dough into the middle" and "rotate the dough by a quarter turn."[1](https://www.supergoldenbakes.com/quick-and-easy-croissants-from-scratch/)

**Lamination Process:** The recipe instructs to "roll it out again repeating steps 5-7 three more times. The dough will become more elastic as you are rolling and folding it."[1](https://www.supergoldenbakes.com/quick-and-easy-croissants-from-scratch/) After folding, wrap the dough and refrigerate for a couple of hours or overnight.

**Shaping:** "Roll the dough out to a rectangle three times as long as it is wide and at least 4mm thick" and "cut the dough into triangles about 30cm/12in long and 8cm/3in at the base."[1](https://www.supergoldenbakes.com/quick-and-easy-croissants-from-scratch/)

## **Recipe 2: Ultimate Traditional Croissants (27 Layers)**

This recipe from The Ultimate Croissant Making Tutorial promises "27 perfect layers of butter wrapped up in delicious dough" that yields "12 large croissants with a lot of layers!"[2](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GxDn4yz5F_Y)

**Dough Ingredients:**
- 500g bread flour (anything with more than 10% protein)
- 150g water, cold
- 150g whole milk, straight out of the fridge
- 55g sugar
- 25g fresh yeast
- 9g salt[2](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GxDn4yz5F_Y)

**Butter Block:**
- 250g unsalted butter
- Egg white for coating[2](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GxDn4yz5F_Y)

**Instructions:**

**Shaping Guidelines:** For proper croissants, "the common guideline is to go for a triangle that has 10 centimetres in base and 28 centimeters in height and also the thickness of a croissant it's about 4 millimeters."[2](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GxDn4yz5F_Y)

**Rolling Technique:** Roll the dough to "28 centimeters in height" and "hopefully you can roll it out in length to be 60 centimeters so that you get 12 croissants."[2](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GxDn4yz5F_Y)

**Baking:** "Bake at 210°C (410°F) for around 6min, then lower to 160°C (320°F) for another 10-12min until golden brown."[2](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GxDn4yz5F_Y)

## **Professional Tips**

For those seeking professional guidance, Anna Olson's method suggests rolling "the dough to a rectangle about 16-inches by 12-inches" and letting "the croissants rise for 2 hours" before baking at "375 F (190 C)" for "about 15 minutes until a rich golden brown."[4](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K689erbK3XI)

The first recipe is ideal for beginners wanting to try croissant-making without the intensive lamination process, while the second provides the traditional method for achieving those classic flaky layers that make authentic French croissants so special.

Great — here’s a concise list of what you’ll need to make croissants (covers both a “quick” simplified method and a traditional laminated method). After this I’ll ask about what you actually have.

Essential equipment
- Digital scale (accurate to 1 g)
- Rolling pin
- Sharp knife or pizza cutter (for triangles)
- Bench scraper
- Pastry brush
- Large mixing bowl(s)
- Baking sheets and parchment paper or silicone mats
- Refrigerator with room to chill dough and butter block
- Freezer (helpful for quick chilling)
- Oven that can reach ~210°C / 410°F
- Cooling rack

Very helpful / makes the process easier
- Stand mixer with dough hook (speeds dough development)
- Pastry sheeter (if available, otherwise rolling pin)
- Proofing box or warm spot for final proving (or an oven with light on)
- Ruler or straight edge (for consistent triangles)
- Plastic wrap and cling film
- Thermometer (oven and/or dough temp)

Ingredients (typical for 12–24 croissants; scale to recipe)
- Bread flour / strong flour
- Milk (whole milk preferred) and/or water
- Yeast (active dry, instant, or fresh—quantities vary by recipe)
- Sugar
- Salt
- Unsalted butter (a lot — for lamination; usually ~200–300 g for 500 g flour)
- Egg(s) for egg wash (yolk or whole egg)
- Optional: extra butter for enrichments, fillings (chocolate, almond), and glaze

Time and space expectations
- Traditional laminated croissants: plan 8–24 hours (mixing, rest/chill, 3–4 turns with chilling, proofing, bake). Often done over two days.
- Quick/simplified methods: can be done in 2–4 hours with shortcuts and warm proofing, but flakiness is reduced.
- You’ll need a cool, uncluttered bench area for rolling and room in the fridge for flat dough/bloc of butter.

Other considerations / pantry items
- Cold environment helps — butter should stay cold while laminating
- Plenty of bench flour or a pastry cloth to prevent sticking
- Space to proof croissants without drafts (avoid overly warm, humid spots)

messages.content:
No problem — a stand mixer isn’t required. You can make excellent croissants by hand or with small appliances. Quick notes and tips, then one question.

How to proceed without a stand mixer
- Hand-mixing/kneading: combine ingredients to a shaggy dough, rest (autolyse) 20–30 minutes, then hand-knead 6–10 minutes until smooth and elastic (windowpane test). Dough will be tacky but manageable.  
- Food processor option: pulse just until the dough comes together — don’t overheat or overwork it.  
- Slap-and-fold: works well for higher-hydration doughs if you’re comfortable using this method to develop gluten.  
- Lamination considerations (same whether mixed by hand or machine): keep dough and butter cold; chill 20–30 minutes between folds; aim for 3 turns (simple: letter fold and book fold variations); use a rolling pin to roll evenly.  
- Timing: plan extra resting time since hand development can be slower; consider an overnight retard (proof in fridge) for convenience and flavor.

A couple quick practical tips
- Use a digital scale for accuracy — croissant ratios matter.  
- Keep a ruler nearby for consistent triangle sizes.  
- If your bench gets warm, chill the dough/butter briefly in the freezer (10–15 min) rather than the fridge.  
- Test dough readiness with the windowpane test rather than relying on time alone.

Great — here are two ingredient lists (one “quick” simplified method and one traditional laminated method). I give yields and key substitution notes so you can tell me what you have.

Quick / simplified croissants (yields ~8–10 medium croissants)
- Bread/strong flour: 250 g  
- Cold unsalted butter (for laminating): 150 g  
- Milk (tepid): 120 ml  
- Active dry yeast (or instant): 7 g (1 packet)  
- Sugar: 30–40 g (≈3 tbsp)  
- Salt: 3 g (½ tsp)  
- Egg yolk or whole egg for egg wash: 1  
- Optional: extra butter for brushing or fillings (chocolate, jam)

Traditional laminated croissants (yields ~12 medium-large croissants)
- Bread/strong flour: 500 g  
- Cold water: 150 g  
- Cold whole milk: 150 g  (or use 300 g total liquid as your recipe indicates)  
- Instant yeast: 8–10 g (or fresh yeast ~25 g — if using fresh, use amount the recipe specifies)  
- Sugar: 50–60 g  
- Salt: 9 g  
- Unsalted butter in dough (optional enrichment): 30–50 g  
- Butter for lamination (butter block): 250–300 g cold, high-fat unsalted (European-style if possible)  
- Eggs for egg wash: 1 whole egg (or 1 egg + 1 yolk for extra shine)  
- Optional: fillings (dark chocolate batons, almond paste, ham & cheese)

Pantry / equipment consumables you’ll also need
- Parchment paper or silicone mat  
- Plastic wrap / cling film  
- Flour for dusting  
- Ruler/pizza cutter/knife for cutting triangles

Key substitution notes
- Yeast: instant ≈ 40% of fresh weight. If you tell me what yeast you have, I’ll convert amounts.  
- Flour: bread/strong flour is best. AP will work but expect slightly less structure.  
- Butter: use unsalted; European-style (82–84% fat) gives better flavor and plasticity. Avoid spreadable or low-fat butter.  
- Eggs: whole egg or yolk for wash — yolk gives deeper color.

messages.content:
No problem — that’s easy to work around. Quick summary, then one question.

Substitution rules
- Active dry yeast → instant: use about 125% of the instant amount (i.e., 1.25x). Active dry is best rehydrated/“proofed” first.  
- Fresh (cake) yeast → instant: fresh ≈ 3× instant (so instant ≈ fresh ÷ 3).  
- No yeast: you can use a sourdough starter (needs recipe adjustments) but chemical leaveners (baking powder/soda) won’t produce proper laminated croissants.

Examples (based on the recipes we discussed)
- If a recipe calls for 8–10 g instant (traditional 500 g flour recipe): use ~10–12.5 g active dry, or ~25–30 g fresh yeast.  
- If a recipe calls for 7 g instant (quick recipe, 250 g flour): use ~8.5–9 g active dry, or ~21 g fresh.

How to use active dry yeast in croissant dough
1. Proof: dissolve the active dry yeast and a pinch of the recipe sugar in about 2–3 tbsp warm water or milk at ~38–43°C (100–110°F). Wait 5–10 minutes until foamy.  
2. Incorporate: add the foamy mix into your dough liquids. If the dough must be kept cold for lamination, let the proofed yeast cool slightly so you don’t overheat the dough.  
3. Fermentation: because you’re using hand-mixing and likely want cooler dough, consider a slow bulk ferment in the fridge (overnight) for better flavor and easier lamination, or use a slightly longer room-temp bulk proof.
